title: 103_s9
content: The Act is titled the "Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 1993" and amends the Impoundment Control Act of 1974 to include a new title granting the President legislative line item veto rescission authority. The "Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 1993" grants the President the authority to rescind budget authority under certain conditions, including balancing the budget, reducing the deficit, and not harming essential government functions or national interest. The President must notify Congress within 20 days of enacting an appropriations Act. The President has the authority to rescind budget authority under the "Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 1993" by notifying Congress within 20 days. The rescission is effective unless a rescission disapproval bill is enacted within the specified period. The President can rescind budget authority under the Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 1993 by notifying Congress within 20 days. Congress must act on the rescission disapproval bill within 20 days, followed by 10 days for the President to sign or veto the bill. If vetoed, an additional 5 days are given. If a special message is sent during a Congress session that ends before the specified period, the rescission does not take effect. If a special message is sent during a Congress session that ends before the specified period, the rescission shall not take effect. The message shall be deemed retransmitted on the first day of the succeeding Congress, and the review period shall begin after that day. "Definitions: A rescission disapproval bill refers to a bill or joint resolution that disapproves a rescission of budget authority in a special message from the President. Part B involves Congressional consideration of legislative line item veto rescissions through a presidential special message." Whenever the President rescinds budget authority, a special message must be sent to Congress detailing the amount, where the authority was available, reasons for the rescission, estimated effects, and all relevant facts and considerations. The President must send a special message to Congress when rescinding budget authority, detailing the amount, reasons, and estimated effects on programs. Each special message transmitted under sections 1101 and 1111 must be delivered to the House of Representatives and the Senate on the same day. It will be referred to the appropriate committees and printed in the Federal Register. Sec. 1113 outlines the referral and floor consideration process for rescission disapproval bills in the Senate. Any bill introduced in response to a special message is referred to the appropriate committees. Debate on such bills is limited to 10 hours, with additional restrictions on debatable motions and appeals. The Senate has rules for the consideration of rescission disapproval bills, limiting debate to 10 hours and restricting debatable motions and appeals. A motion to further limit debate is not debatable, and a motion to recommit is not in order. In the Senate and House of Representatives, it is not allowed to consider any rescission disapproval bill that does not relate to the rescission of budget authority transmitted by the President. Amendments to a rescission disapproval bill are also not permitted, unless waived by a three-fifths vote in the Senate.
